perturbation.original_text: Overdue payments hereunder shall be subject to a late payment charge calculated at an annual rate of three percent (3%) over the prime rate or successive prime rates (as posted in New York City) during delinquency. If the amount of such charge exceeds the maximum permitted by law, such charge shall be reduced to such maximum.
perturbation.changed_text: Overdue payments hereunder shall be subject to a late payment charge calculated at an annual rate of three percent (3%) over the prime rate or successive prime rates (as posted in New York City) during delinquency.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the clause that reduces the late payment charge to the maximum permitted by law, the contract could potentially violate Pennsylvania usury laws if the calculated late fee exceeds the legal limit. This omission creates a legal risk for THI, who is responsible for the payments.
perturbation.law_explanation: Pennsylvania law sets limits on the interest rates that can be charged on loans and other debts. By removing the provision that ensures compliance with these limits, the contract now potentially violates the law if the interest rate exceeds the legally allowed amount.  The changed text creates a situation where the contract could demand illegal interest and/or late fees, which violates Pennsylvania's legal and financial protections.

perturbation.original_text: Each Party agrees to hold in confidence confidential information acquired in the course of this relationship with the other Parties and their associates. Each Party agrees to refrain from, either during period of this Agreement or at any other time thereafter, disclosing, using or disseminating such confidential information, for its or another's benefit, in any way acquired in the course of any association arising out of this Agreement. For purposes of this Agreement, confidential information shall include contacts and introductions to third parties and information relating thereto. Confidential information, knowledge or data of a Party and/or its affiliates shall not include any information which is or becomes generally available to the public other than as a result of a disclosure by such Party or its representatives.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party agrees to hold in confidence confidential information acquired in the course of this relationship with the other Parties and their associates. Each Party agrees to refrain from, either during period of this Agreement or at any time thereafter, disclosing, using or disseminating such confidential information, for its or another's benefit, in any way acquired in the course of any association arising out of this Agreement. For purposes of this Agreement, confidential information shall include contacts and introductions to third parties and information relating thereto.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause contains an exception to confidentiality: 'Confidential information, knowledge or data of a Party and/or its affiliates shall not include any information which is or becomes generally available to the public other than as a result of a disclosure by such Party or its representatives.' Removing this exception means that even information that becomes publicly available through no fault of the receiving party must be kept confidential. This arguably infringes upon the right to free speech and dissemination of information, particularly concerning information that would otherwise be considered public knowledge, creating a legal conflict in Pennsylvania, where the agreement is governed.
perturbation.law_explanation: Article I, Section 7 of the Pennsylvania Constitution guarantees freedom of speech and the press. The modified clause infringes on this right by preventing a party from disclosing information that is already publicly available, regardless of how it became public. By removing the exemption for publicly available information, the agreement now imposes a broader restriction on speech than the constitution allows, potentially violating the constitutional right to disseminate information already in the public domain.

perturbation.original_text: Venue for any action brought under this Agreement shall be in the appropriate court in Mercer County, Pennsylvania.
perturbation.changed_text: Venue for any action brought under this Agreement shall be exclusively in a court selected by Marv Enterprises, LLC.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause specifies Mercer County, Pennsylvania, as the venue. The modified text gives Marv Enterprises, LLC the sole power to choose the venue. This could violate Pennsylvania's rules regarding forum selection clauses, especially if the chosen venue is unreasonable or designed to disadvantage the other parties. Pennsylvania law requires that forum selection clauses be freely negotiated and not impose an undue burden. Giving one party unilateral control over venue introduces a potential legal contradiction.
perturbation.law_explanation: Pennsylvania Rule of Civil Procedure 1006(d)(1) addresses forum selection clauses and requires them to be reasonable. While not explicitly outlawing them, Pennsylvania courts scrutinize such clauses to ensure they are not the result of unequal bargaining power or impose an unreasonable burden on one party. By granting Marv Enterprises, LLC the exclusive right to select the venue, the modified clause creates a risk that the selected venue will be inconvenient or unduly burdensome for the other parties, potentially leading to a challenge under Rule 1006(d)(1). This could be seen as an attempt to circumvent the standard venue rules and disadvantage Premier or THI in potential litigation.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_1: 231 Pa. Code Rule 1006. Venue. Change of Venue. Rule 1006. Venue. Change of Venue. (a) General Rule. Except as otherwise provided by subdivisions (b) and (c) of this rule, an action against an individual may be brought in and only in a county where (1) the individual may be served; (2) the cause of action arose; (3) a transaction or occurrence took place out of which the cause of action arose; (4) venue is authorized by law; or (5) the property or a part of the property, which is the subject matter of the action, is located provided that equitable relief is sought with respect to the property. (b) Venue Designated by Rule. Actions against the following defendants, except as otherwise provided in subdivision (c), may be brought in and only in the counties designated by the following rules: political subdivisions, Rule 2103; partnerships, Rule 2130; unincorporated associations, Rule 2156; corporations and similar entities, Rule 2179. (c) Joint and Several Liability Actions. An action to enforce a joint or joint and several liability against two or more defendants, except actions in which the Commonwealth is a party defendant, may be brought against all defendants in any county in which the venue may be laid against any one of the defendants under the general rules of subdivisions (a) or (b). (d) Transfer of Venue. (1) For the convenience of parties and witnesses , the court upon petition of any party may transfer an action to the appropriate court of any other county where the action could originally have been brought. (2) If, upon petition and hearing, the court finds that a fair and impartial trial cannot be held in the county for reasons stated of record, the court may order that the action be transferred. The order changing venue shall be certified to the Supreme Court, which shall designate the county to which the case is to be transferred.
